reviews.review_msg: I was very lucky to take 3 courses with Evan at SFU. He is truly an exceptional and inspirational instructor. PSYC 382 can be overwhelming at times, but his teaching style is clear, concise and engaging. I learned so much from his lectures and discussions. His exams are fair and directly related to content.

My fav psyc prof so far. Sometimes his notes were a little bit hard to understand (you really have to know and understand bio psych vocab and concepts) but nonetheless if u attend lectures, you'll understand the material very well! His exams were always fair as well, so sad he's leaving, we love prof caldbick :(

Evan is such an amazing professor, one of the best in Psyc. He genuinely cares for his students and has a passion for teaching unlike many profs at SFU. It is a huge disappointment that SFU doesn't value him as much as his students do, and he will be greatly missed.

One of the best profs at SFU. Evan teaches some of the most difficult material in psych, but has clear explanations & encourages questions. He always checks in with students to see how we are doing & whether he needs to slow down, speed up, or find a different metaphor to explain something. Tests are difficult but he supports students to succeed.

Evan is probably one of my favourite profs I've had at SFU, he's young, engaging, knowledgeable, well read and very passionate about his studied fields. It's important to ask questions, engage in lecture and be prepared for lecture and quizzes by doing your readings. I liked this prof so much that I am taking another course with him next semester

Such an awesome dude. Course was very challenging, but it should be. I felt very dumb many times but this course is great if you enjoy a challenge. Very open to feedback and very accessible: he just wants you to do well and understand the material. Very passionate and very well read so great for conversation related or unrelated to course content.

I took this course with very little knowledge in bio-psych. But thanks to his great teaching style and skills, I ended up doing very well.  He is very passionate about the field he teaches, and his passion is contageous.  Helpful, kind, and FUNNY. Totally recommended.
nice guy.. not so good prof. incredibly unclear and messed grading scheme for final grades. I would not take 382 again...ever....

I'm gonna have to suggest not taking a course with Steven. He is a very nice guy and tries very hard to help students, but somehow it just doesn't work out that well. In any case, lectures are very disorganized (although slides are good) and the tests are soo bizarre. Fair marking but so hard to study for the tests because the course sucks.

He is a great prof, the course 382 was not made by him. It is originally taught by John Macdonald who is freakin jerk and only cares about his own research. Im so glad we have Steven instead of John. Cool guy

Steven is a good professor. He comes from the USA and is just new to SFU so I think it'll take some getting used to our school for him. But he is a really nice guy and is totally willing to help anyone that needs help. Very very fair marker. Sometimes he is a little unclear in his lecturing, but is very organized and has great powerpoint slides.
He's a good teacher if cognitive neuroscience is your thing
Prof is really nice and easy going but very disorganized
No Comments
very helpful and willing to spend the time to go over all questions on the exam
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments

You can't rely on only the textbook because Dr. Liotti's powerpoint slides say very different, sometimes contradictory things. Lectures were very hard to follow. The SA and essay questions on the exams were brutal. The quizzes and multiple choice were fine. His powerpoint slides need a serious makeover - messy to the point where they're unreadable.

Not a fan. His tests are super hard, mostly because they're poorly written. His lectures are absolutely dry, too scattered & hard to understand. The textbook is way more helpful explaining concepts, sometimes he would confuse me. BUT, he can be funny & his notes attached to lecture slides are helpful studying for quizzes. All in all a GPA downer.
Good professor but he can he hard to understand at times. Study his lecture notes/attend class and you'll do fine -- more emphasis on lecture material.

Although English isn't his first language and he sometimes loses his train of thought mid-sentence, he's a good teacher. His interest in the subject is high and he has a lot of fun stuff to share about his research.

He is a great guy.  I think that the people who do poorly in his courses need to read their textbooks better.  His exams are long, but if you study properly it is not really a problem.  He is one of the best biopsychology professors at SFU and I have enormous respect for him, as he is internationally recognized as being a leader in his field.
Nice guy and good to talk to but unorganized. He's helpful, knowledgeable, and can answer almost any question but his mind seems to be elsewhere at times.

He's not a bad, but VERY disorganized and hard to understand at times as English is his second language. His tests were fair, but I don't know about the papers because he never gave us our marks! Not only that, but he forgot about the first class, didn't bring enough exams to the midterm and posted the wrong final marks. He needs to figure it out.

Please take PSYC382 with Dr. S. Extremely knowledgeable (Ph.D in neuroscience), but also so approachable. Lectures are engaging: encourages questions , shows videos, etc. Midterms are very fair and makes study guides questions to study from. In Class quizzes too. Would definitely take a class with her again. START ON THE RESEARCH PROPOSAL EARLY.

Dr. L does a really good job of making the class a chill learning environment, very open to discussion and questions. The class material's quite complex, but she does an excellent job of explaining it and showing the material in multiple forms (e.g. example videos). Tests are MC and SA, and only one (fairly small) term project.
